block.p: Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended May 26, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Editor's Choice

ON CHESIL BEACH, by Ian McEwan. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $22.) Consisting largely of a single sex scene played out on a couple's wedding night, this seeming novel of manners is as much a horror story as any McEwan has written. AFTER DARK, by Haruki Murakami. Translated by Jay Rubin. (Knopf, $22.95.) A tale of two sisters, one awake all night, one asleep for months.Right Livelihoods: Three Novellas, by Rick Moody. (Little, Brown, $23.99.) In the longest story here, New Yorkers react with passivity and denial after a nuclear attack in Lower Manhattan.A DAY AT THE BEACH, by Helen Schulman. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) The events of 9/11 upend the lives of a glamorous TriBeCa couple.CONSIDERING DORIS DAY, by Tom Santopietro. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $25.95.) Avoiding sensationalism, this sympathetic biography concentrates on Day's multifaceted career.The Life of Kingsley Amis, by Zachary Leader. (Pantheon, $39.95.) The author of ''Lucky Jim'' turned drunkenness, bonhomie and lechery into the sources of serious literary pleasure.THE MINISTRY OF SPECIAL CASES, by Nathan Englander. (Knopf, $25.) A novel of a Jewish family caught up in Argentina's ''Dirty War.'' SHROOM: A Cultural History of the Magic Mushroom, by Andy Letcher. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $25.95.) Letcher's revisionist history is a delightful journalistic addition to the ''trip lit'' genre. SPY WARS: Moles, Mysteries, and Deadly Games, by Tennent H. Bagley. (Yale University, $28.) A former counterintelligence officer takes a provocative view of the case of the K.G.B. defector Yuri Nosenko, an unresolved cold-war mystery.Alias the Cat! by Kim Deitch. (Pantheon, $23.) In graphic-autobiographical mode, Deitch follows Waldo the Cat, his foul-mouthed feline muse, from one strange world to the next.Shadowland, by Kim Deitch. (Fantagraphics, paper, $18.95.) In this crazy, invigorating comic collection, Deitch charts the scoundrel's progress of the creepily clown-faced lout Al Ledicker. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

ON CHESIL BEACH, by Ian McEwan. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $22.) Consisting largely of a single sex scene played out on a couple's wedding night, this seeming novel of manners is as much a horror story as any McEwan has written. AFTER DARK, by Haruki Murakami. Translated by Jay Rubin. (Knopf, $22.95.) A tale of two sisters, one awake all night, one asleep for months.Right Livelihoods: Three Novellas, by Rick Moody. (Little, Brown, $23.99.) Avoiding sensationalism, this sympathetic biography concentrates on Day's multifaceted career.The Life of Kingsley Amis, by Zachary Leader. (Pantheon, $39.95.) The author of ''Lucky Jim'' turned drunkenness, bonhomie and lechery into the sources of serious literary pleasure.THE MINISTRY OF SPECIAL CASES, by Nathan Englander. (Knopf, $25.) A novel of a Jewish family caught up in Argentina's ''Dirty War.'' SHROOM: A Cultural History of the Magic Mushroom, by Andy Letcher. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $25.95.) Letcher's revisionist history is a delightful journalistic addition to the ''trip lit'' genre. SPY WARS: Moles, Mysteries, and Deadly Games, by Tennent H. Bagley. (Yale University, $28.) A former counterintelligence officer takes a provocative view of the case of the K.G.B. defector Yuri Nosenko, an unresolved cold-war mystery.Alias the Cat! by Kim Deitch. (Pantheon, $23.) In graphic-autobiographical mode, Deitch follows Waldo the Cat, his foul-mouthed feline muse, from one strange world to the next.Shadowland, by Kim Deitch. (Fantagraphics, paper, $18.95.) In this crazy, invigorating comic collection, Deitch charts the scoundrel's progress of the creepily clown-faced lout Al Ledicker. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Weeks
This Last On
Week Week List FICTION
1 A THOUSAND SPLENDID SUNS, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead, $25.95.) A friendship between two women in Afghanistan against the backdrop of 30 years of war; from the author of ''The Kite Runner.''

1 THE OVERLOOK, by Michael Connelly. (Little, Brown, $21.99.) The Los Angeles detective Harry Bosch tangles with the F.B.I. and Homeland Security as he tries to solve the case of a murdered physicist with access to radioactive materials.
3 1 3 THE 6TH TARGET, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) In San Francisco, children are disappearing, and Detective Lindsay Boxer and the Women's Murder Club investigate.
4 3 2 INVISIBLE PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $26.95.) The Minneapolis detective Lucas Davenport finds connections between the murder of several elderly residents and a political scandal.
5 2 2 BAD LUCK AND TROUBLE, by Lee Child. (Delacorte, $26.) Jack Reacher must discover who is hunting down members of a team of former military investigators.

6 6 6 THE CHILDREN OF H√ÉRIN, by J. R. R. Tolkien. Edited by Christopher Tolkien. Illustrated by Alan Lee. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) In Middle-earth, an evil lord wants to destroy his rival's children.
7 4 4 THE YIDDISH POLICEMEN'S UNION, by Michael Chabon. (HarperCollins, $26.95.) A detective investigates a neighbor's murder in a Jewish settlement in Alaska.
8 5 5 SIMPLE GENIUS, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $26.99.) Two former Secret Service agents investigate a scientist's murder while one battles her own demons.
9 8 4 RANT, by Chuck Palahniuk. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The ''oral biography'' of a serial killer.
10 14 2 THE QUEST, by Wilbur Smith. (Thomas Dunne, $27.95.) In ancient Egypt, a magus searches for the cause of a series of plagues.
11* 9 6 THE WOODS, by Harlan Coben. (Dutton, $26.95.) A prosecutor must confront family secrets when new evidence surfaces about a murder and disappearance at a summer camp 20 years earlier.
12 10 12 NINETEEN MINUTES, by Jodi Picoult. (Atria, $26.95.) The aftermath of a high school shooting reveals the fault lines in a small New Hampshire town.
13 7 2 Pearl Harbor, by Newt Gingrich and William R. Forstchen. (Thomas Dunne, $25.95.) The buildup to the historic attack, with an alternative ending.
14 13 6 THE GOOD HUSBAND OF ZEBRA DRIVE, by Alexander McCall Smith. (Pantheon, $21.95.) The eighth novel in the No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency series.
15 12 5 BODY SURFING, by Anita Shreve. (Little, Brown, $25.99.) A woman takes a job as a tutor and becomes involved in a wealthy family's tensions and rivalries.
Weeks
This Last On
Week Week List NONFICTION
1 THE ASSAULT ON REASON, by Al Gore. (Penguin Press, $25.95.) How the Bush administration has degraded the political environment through secrecy, fear and the rejection of fact-based reasoning.
1 THE REAGAN DIARIES, by Ronald Reagan. Edited by Douglas Brinkley. (HarperCollins, $35.) Selections from the 40th president's daily White House diaries.
3 2 7 EINSTEIN, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $32.) A biography based on newly released personal letters.
4 1 4 GOD IS NOT GREAT, by Christopher Hitchens. (Twelve, $24.99.) Religion as a malignant force in the world.
5 7 3 PRESIDENTIAL COURAGE, by Michael Beschloss. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) Profiles of nine presidents who had the courage to make unpopular decisions.
6 5 15 A LONG WAY GONE, by Ishmael Beah. (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) A former child soldier from Sierra Leone describes his drug-crazed killing spree and his return to humanity.
7 6 2 JESUS OF NAZARETH, by Benedict XVI. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The pope discusses Jesus' identity as revealed in the Gospels.
8 3 4 ANIMAL, VEGETABLE, MIRACLE, by Barbara Kingsolver with Steven L. Hopp and Camille Kingsolver. (HarperCollins, $26.95.) The novelist and her family spend a year eating homegrown or local food.

9 9 6 WHERE HAVE ALL THE LEADERS GONE?, by Lee Iacocca. (Scribner, $25.) The former C.E.O. of Chrysler protests the lack of political and business leadership on issues like health care and energy policy.
10 15 2 RICKLES' BOOK, by Don Rickles with David Ritz. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) A memoir by the insult comedian.
11 13 5 THE BLACK SWAN, by Nassim Nicholas Taleb. (Random House, $26.95.) The role of the unexpected.
12* 8 4 AT THE CENTER OF THE STORM, by George Tenet. (HarperCollins, $30.) The former director of the Central Intelligence Agency looks back on his career.
13 4 2 PLATO and A PLATYPUS WALK INTO A BAR, by Thomas Cathcart and Daniel Klein. (Abrams Image, $18.95.) A humorous tour of philosophical traditions.
14 10 3 TALES FROM Q SCHOOL, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $26.99.) Inside the 2005 PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament, from the author of ''A Good Walk Spoiled.''
15* 11 8 PAULA DEEN: IT AIN'T ALL ABOUT THE COOKIN', by Paula Deen with Sherry Suib Cohen. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A memoir with recipes from the Southern cooking impresario.
1 BROTHERS, by David Talbot. (Free Press, $28.) An assessment of John F. Kennedy's administration and a plea for a new effort to uncover the truth about his assassination.
